channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: What makes a great 'Scrooge'?
item.description: Elena Burnett and Barrie Hardymon on why Ebenezer Scrooge keeps returning to the screen, and what makes a great Christmas Carol adaptation endure.
item.content:encoded: Elena Burnett and Barrie Hardymon on why Ebenezer Scrooge keeps returning to the screen, and what makes a great Christmas Carol adaptation endure.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: In 'The Beast in Me', a new neighbor becomes the wrong kind of muse
item.description: Claire Danes talks about her new role stepping into the mind of a writer tempted by a dangerous mystery.
item.content:encoded: Claire Danes talks about her new role stepping into the mind of a writer tempted by a dangerous mystery.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: European leaders lock in Ukraine funding amid renewed peace efforts
item.description: The European Union's ambassador to the U.S. argues that Europe's latest financing move strengthens Ukraine's hand at a fragile moment in peace negotiations.
item.content:encoded: The European Union's ambassador to the U.S. argues that Europe's latest financing move strengthens Ukraine's hand at a fragile moment in peace negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Henry Larson

item.title: Is a country full of election skeptics actually ready for online voting?
item.description: Entrepreneur, political strategist and philanthropist Bradley Tusk argues his new online voting tech could revolutionize participation in American elections. Through his organization, the Mobile Voting Project, he wants to make online voting a reality - even at a time when much of the election establishment thinks that is a very bad idea.
item.content:encoded: Entrepreneur, political strategist and philanthropist Bradley Tusk argues his new online voting tech could revolutionize participation in American elections. Through his organization, the Mobile Voting Project, he wants to make online voting a reality - even at a time when much of the election establishment thinks that is a very bad idea.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: 'Scandalized' podcast argues political scandals are more than gossip
item.description: NPR's Miles Parks talks with political scientists Charlie Hunt and Jaci Kettler about their podcast "Scandalized" which unpacks political scandals from American history.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Miles Parks talks with political scientists Charlie Hunt and Jaci Kettler about their podcast "Scandalized" which unpacks political scandals from American history.
item.dc:creator: Mallory Yu

item.title: Cartagena's iconic horse carriages give way to electric buggies
item.description: Cartagena, Colombia, is set to ban its iconic horse-drawn carriages, replacing them with electric buggies — a move dividing the historic city over tradition, tourism, and animal welfare.
item.content:encoded:
Cartagena, Colombia, is set to ban its iconic horse-drawn carriages, replacing them with electric buggies — a move dividing the historic city over tradition, tourism, and animal welfare.

(Image credit: Jeffrey Greenberg)
item.dc:creator: Manuel Rueda

item.title: Why 'Marty Supreme' marks a new chapter for Josh Safdie
item.description: Josh Safdie discusses his upcoming film 'Marty Supreme', set for release on December 25.
item.content:encoded: Josh Safdie discusses his upcoming film 'Marty Supreme', set for release on December 25.
item.dc:creator: Marc Rivers

item.title: The quiet pull of introspective songs as temperatures fall
item.description: When temperatures drop, why do many listeners find themselves gravitating toward more introspective, emotionally resonant songs?
item.content:encoded: When temperatures drop, why do many listeners find themselves gravitating toward more introspective, emotionally resonant songs?
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: Homeowners stall Connecticut's push for more housing
item.description: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.content:encoded: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.dc:creator: Molly Ingram

item.title: What lawmakers advanced, and stalled, on health care this week
item.description: Julie Rovner, chief Washington correspondent for KFF Health News, on Congress's healthcare stalemate and what it means for ACA marketplace shoppers.
item.content:encoded: Julie Rovner, chief Washington correspondent for KFF Health News, on Congress's healthcare stalemate and what it means for ACA marketplace shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Rovner
